instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Hi,
Received the MacBook in for non-responsive keyboard. Upon inspection, Unit was fully working with the external keyboard. It would accept keyboard shortcuts at boot but nothing once we were in os. We found quite a few places with liquid residue. Put it through cleanup in crest ultrasonic cleaner. It will not power on now, no chime, no backlight no spin. I have 3rd party charger that goes green when plugged.
Had a look under a microscope and nothing pops out.
Please advise

Kind regards,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Remove keyboard and connect magsafe; does it turn on?

Be aware of ultrasonic cleaners w/o sweep function.
Change the board position every 30s and do not let it more than 10min total in the bath.

Post some voltages in the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> areas.
Check if <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> is still in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
I tried with speaker and fan only. I might have messed it up as it was definitely longer than 10 min but my crest has a sweeping function, its the recommended one for those jobs. <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> present. <CAPACITOR>C7101</CAPACITOR> is 5.45v <CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR> same <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> 16.45V, <CAPACITOR>C7122</CAPACITOR> 14.33v, <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> 0v those are around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
<CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR> 8.15v ( i am guessing the component here as my board view is a bit different to the board I have) that's the only cap I found around the <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 voltages you get.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  12.5v, 3V42 3.4v
Checked each in 2 different points

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulsing at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Yeah post voltages for <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. If you have all of those, then check for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> like 2informaticos asked for

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
All 3.3 lines have 3.3v
I am getting 4.9v on <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> that's part of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, but 0v on two components on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> also 0v

Those checks I do with only power connected, The light on the charger switches from green to amber and back to green in 10 sec intervals

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulsing at least?"
You can also check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse once, or every 5sec.
If not, post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.

Does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> react if you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
If not, check all PCH's RTC signal, and 32KHz clock from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Unfortunately, I don't have an oscilloscope :( I believe I would need it to see the pulsing?
Just a multimeter to use
I am not totally new but still learning.
The multimeter doesn't pick up any voltage
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.37v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.03v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.28v

I am hoping it is still possible to assess the board without the oscilloscope 

Not sure how to trigger the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, it seems to be on 3.4v all the time unless I am doing something wrong
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> also constantly on 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
"Not sure how to trigger the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, it seems to be on 3.4v all the time"
Force it 1s to ground, like pressing power button; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads.

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.03v"
PCH will not start Power On Sequence then...
Did you try original 85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Thanks for all the help

After triggering, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> jumped from 3.4v to 2.6v and back to 3.4v
I am testing without the battery being plugged in - not sure if that matters
Just tried plugging it in with an original 45w charger and battery/fan/speaker. Got a chime but no fan spin so I disconnected it - not sure if that helps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
The fan starts later on this board, when something gets hot...
Do you have USB activity?
Also check for image, even if no backlight present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Yeah the fan doesn't spin on this model until the CPU heats up. Light on USB mouse with the chime? If so exactly what 2informaticos said check for image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Ok, it started up, somehow it starts up now. Get the picture, black screen "question mark folder", doesn't see the disk for some reason, the keyboard also doesn't work. I tried the ssd in another mac and its booting and loading os so it must be something to do with the motherboard. Should I start another topic? or can I continue here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Continue here...
Keyboard/trackpad work in boot menu and don't work under OSX?
Check traces around SSD connector; post voltages (with SSD inserted) for <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
the <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> pin1 - 3.4v, pin 2 - 0v, pin 8 - 0.08v, (I checked those when plugged but not on)
The keyboard seems to be completely unresponsive now, apart of the power button, no trackpad either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:

You cannot access boot menu even?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Sorry, I could find the J3470, neither on the schematics nor in BoardView, I am obviously missing something. I had to plug in the external keyboard to Alt boot, internal keyboard didn't let me do that

threads.message: J3700 i think! Let me check it now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: [URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/41437-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-wont-turn-on?_=1540920153704&_=1540923541988"]3[/URL].3v on the J3700 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FLT</SIGNAL> I hope that is the one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: Sorry, my mistake; read <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> instead of J3740...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>

Pin 1 3.4v , Pin 2 0.98V, Pin 6 3.22v
While on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: What about the other pins???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message: sorry, Pin 3 - 3.28v, pin 4 - 3.43, pin 5 - 0v,  pin 7 - 0.022v, pin 8 - 0.993v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Strange to have 1V at <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>.
I think PCH cannot recognize the signal.
Low level should be less than 0.8V in theory...
Change <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> and see what happens.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
Hi

Swapped <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>, Pin 8 is now 0v, Pin 6 3.15v other pins are the same, still the same outcome :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
So <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> was bad.
Check again control signals and power rails at J3700.
Pay atention at continuity between J3700.and <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11; maybe need to change them too.
Did you try known good SSD again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
apologies, there are other differences on the <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>
Pin 1 3.43v
Pin 2 0.994v
Pin 3 3.288v
Pin 4 0v
Pin 5 GN
Pin 6 3.25v
Pin 7 starts at 1v and slowly goes down
Pin 8 0v

Maybe I didn't do it right?


J3700

Pin 1 3.33v
other power pins share this power line it seems.
I am sorry to be so ignorant, how would I recognize pins for control signals? How would I test them?

I went through every pin on J3700 and there doesn't seem to be a direct connection to <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11 so that I could test the continuity, I am guessing I am doing it wrong

This SSD works in another MacBook so I don't think its the SSD

Thank you for your patience and the assistance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on
threads.message:
"Pin 4 0v"
That is bad; SSD is kept in reset...
You should get 3V at both pins 3 & 4.
